statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Marquette 88, Lewis 40
article.story: MILWAUKEE (AP) -- Freshman Dominic James scored 22 points to lead Marquette to an 88-40 victory over NCAA Division II opponent Lewis Wednesday night. Steve Novak added 14 points and Jerel McNeal and Joe Chapman 11 apiece to help the Golden Eagles (10-3) win their fourth straight game. James, who hit three 3-pointers, tied the career high in scoring he set Nov. 30 against Nebraska. It was Marquette's final nonconference tuneup before making its Big East debut next Tuesday night against No. 2 Connecticut in Milwaukee. Stephan Bolt had 9 points and John Loeffelholz 8 to lead Lewis (7-4). The Golden Eagles led 33-19 at halftime. A 21-2 second-half scoring run that included a pair of 3-pointers by James put Marquette up 56-22 and ended any hopes the Flyers had of mounting a comeback. Marquette wasted little time establishing its dominance. After Bolt tied the game 2-2, the Golden Eagles went on a 15-0 scoring run to go ahead for good in the contest. Three-pointers by Novak, Joe Chapman and Dan Fitzgerald highlighted the spurt. The Flyers missed 11 shots during the run.
